newsitem.title: JAPAN: NEC, Packard Bell set up PC sales unit in Japan.
newsitem.headline: NEC, Packard Bell set up PC sales unit in Japan.

text.p: NEC Corp said on Monday that it and its U.S. personal computer (PC) affiliate Packard Bell NEC Inc (PB NEC) had jointly established a Japanese unit to sell IBM-compatible PCs in Japan.

The new company, Packard Bell NEC Japan K.K., will sell PB-NEC brand desktop and notebook PCs developed by the U.S. parent, a joint venture set up earlier this year by Packard Bell, U.S. firm Zenith Data Systems, and NEC.
Including non-voting stock, NEC owns about 40 percent of PB NEC, as a result of its $283 million investment in Packard Bell in February, a NEC spokesman said.
The new Japanese unit will also sell Packard Bell-brand PCs in Japan, which have already been sold in Japan for five years.

The new firm, capitalised at 200 million yen, aims to sell a total of 40,000 PCs in the initial year to March 31, 1997, and 150,000 in the second year, its president, Makoto Tsuruta, told a news conference.
NEC's subsidiaries will support the new firm's distribution, maintenance and production, he said.
NEC already sells its own proprietary-architecture PCs in Japan and holds a 40 percent share of the country's PC market.
